heisig_chinese_memo: Looks like a bridge going over a body of water, being supported by columns underneath it. It's a great line of business. I see tourists and vacationers coming and going constantly on the bridge paying their tolls.
heisig_story: By joining the top four strokes, you should get a picture of the front current of a river, the stream trailing behind. Hence the character for going.
koohiiStory1: I use The Flash for for this primitive; a superhero who is always going very fast.
koohiiStory2: To me, this looks like a bridge going over a body of water, being supported by columns underneath it. Being that I live near the ocean, I see tourists and vacationers coming and going constantly on the bridge. Because the bridge is so long, it forms an arc to support the structural integrity. You can see that arc here.

origin_of_ch_char_book: Where the main roads meet, thatâ€™s most likely to be a busy place. There will be lots of markets at such a crossroad. (è¡Œ, xing=Hsing, walk) means an open crossroad in four directions. Since there were many shops around, this word è¡Œ also means â€œshopâ€ or â€œjobâ€ as well as â€œwalkâ€.,The Shang Dynasty was established in a location far away from the sea, so it was difficult to get seashells. Yet very beautiful round seashells are found in the Shang Dynasty tombs. Such precious shells were used as currency. In Hanzi=tzu, many words and symbols refer to seashells. Several words are related to the seashell. For example, (å¾—, de, get) shows hand bending a finger (å¯¸, cun=tsâ€™un, a small unit of length) to pick up a seashell (è´, bei, shellfish, the original type is) on the road. (è¡Œ, xing=hsing, walk). It literally means â€œwalking down to the road and picking up a seashell by chanceâ€.,The Yellow River that flows through China is one of the longest rivers in the world. The river is so long that the ancient Chinese probably thought that it was endless. Therefore, a long riverâ€™s endless flow came to mean â€œforeverâ€. (æ°¸, yong, forever) was created to mean such thoughts. The character shows a person (äºº, ren, human), a road (è¡Œ, xing=hsing, line), and a flow of water . It signifies a man swimming in the river: (æ³³, yong, swim) or walking next to a river. He would think the river is so long, and the flow of water is endless.
humanum_full_description_en:
The road extending in all directions, now called "crossroads". The original meaning is the road, and the road is walked out by people, and the extension is walking. Starting from Luo Zhenyu, people in recent times believed that Xingshi was like "the four-dimensional qu"; later, Karlgren interpreted it as "a drawing of meeting streets". " Xing ", as a radical of ancient characters, is often omitted as "å½³". From the word "å½³", it has a certain relationship with walking or Taoism.

"Said Wen": "Walking, one's steps tend to follow. From å½³ to follow. All those who walk follow the steps." People's step and step are the extended meaning of " action ". Starting from the original meaning of the road, two meanings of walking and ranks are derived. From the meaning of walking, the meanings of popularity, passage, implementation, experience, inspection, and behavior are derived; from the meaning of ranks, the meanings of ranking and industry are derived. It also extends to commercial banks and banks (Qiu Xigui).

The oracle bone inscription means the road, Tunnan 2718: "Tuncai (in) line", which means to meet on the road. It also means walking, "B" 947: "The king cannot walk from the bird", which means that the king does not walk from the bird's ground.

Jin Wen means the road, and Zeng Boyan: "Gold guides (road) tin travel", which means the road to tribute or trade with gold and tin (Guo Moruo). History wall plate: "Hong Lu Mao (Zhao) King, Guang Li Chu Xing (Jing), Fu (Wei) travels south." It means that King Zhou Zhao aggressively attacked Chu and wanted to open the road to plunder metal from the south (Qiu Xigui) ). It also means to walk and travel long distances, Zeng Boyan said: "Going by conquest." Mr. Chen mourned his father: "Use requisition to requisition." Mrs. Fan Long Ying Li: "From the beginning (made) the walking é¬²", "é¬²" is the food vessel, meaning the casting used for traveling. It also expresses behavior and character. Zhongshan Wangding: "Lun (on) its virtue (de), and çœš (province) its behavior." [å¦¾å­]ğ§Š’ Pot: "Germany (Germany) is prosperous ğ¡‰š (wang)". It also means implementation and fulfillment. Zhongshan Wangding: "It is easy to say that a girl (like) is long, and a fool (like) is wise. This is easy to say but difficult to do." origin_of_ch_char_book: Where the main roads meet, thatâ€™s most likely to be a busy place. There will be lots of markets at such a crossroad. (è¡Œ, xing=Hsing, walk) means an open crossroad in four directions. Since there were many shops around, this word è¡Œ also means â€œshopâ€ or â€œjobâ€ as well as â€œwalkâ€.,The Shang Dynasty was established in a location far away from the sea, so it was difficult to get seashells. Yet very beautiful round seashells are found in the Shang Dynasty tombs. Such precious shells were used as currency. In Hanzi=tzu, many words and symbols refer to seashells. Several words are related to the seashell. For example, (å¾—, de, get) shows hand bending a finger (å¯¸, cun=tsâ€™un, a small unit of length) to pick up a seashell (è´, bei, shellfish, the original type is) on the road. (è¡Œ, xing=hsing, walk). It literally means â€œwalking down to the road and picking up a seashell by chanceâ€.,The Yellow River that flows through China is one of the longest rivers in the world. The river is so long that the ancient Chinese probably thought that it was endless. Therefore, a long riverâ€™s endless flow came to mean â€œforeverâ€. (æ°¸, yong, forever) was created to mean such thoughts. The character shows a person (äºº, ren, human), a road (è¡Œ, xing=hsing, line), and a flow of water . It signifies a man swimming in the river: (æ³³, yong, swim) or walking next to a river. He would think the river is so long, and the flow of water is endless.
